DAILY ASIA-PAC OPENING NEWS
content:
ASIA-PAC

China is to further cut import tariffs for consumer goods including clothing, sports clothing, shoes, washing machines, fridges, cosmetics, healthcare and food items from July 1st. (Newswires) In other news, China urged state-owned companies to limit overseas investment risk. (People's Daily)


UK

UK PM May has been told by the leaders of some of Europe's biggest companies that "clarity and certainty" is needed over Brexit because "time is running out". (Sky News)


EU

US is reportedly planning to proceed with tariffs on EU steel and aluminium, while an announcement is expected as soon as Thursday. (WSJ)

Italy's President Mattarella and PM-designate Cottarelli agreed not to rush the situation to see if a political government can be formed, according to a source close to the President. (Newswires)

Italy's Five Star Movement have called for Savona to withdraw candidacy for Economy Minister to allow a government to be formed, while party leader Di Maio said Savona should be part of M5S-League government but not as Economy Minister. Di Maio also noted that an alternative Economy Minister should try to renegotiate treaties in the EU if the League agrees and that the choice is either a snap election or a political government. (Newswires)

The Spanish opposition is seen close to securing votes necessary to remove current PM Rajoy, while his PP party is said to most likely see a defeat in the no confidence vote on Friday. (Newswires)
 

FX

Canadian BoC Rate Decision 1.25% vs. Exp. 1.25% (Prev. 1.25%). (Newswires)
BoC dropped its previous reference to "cautious" policy adjustments, while it stated it will take a gradual approach to rate hikes and that higher rates will be warranted to keep inflation near target. (Newswires)
 

COMMODITIES

US API Weekly Crude Stocks (25 May) 1.001M vs. Exp. -0.500M (Prev. -1.300M). (Newswires)

A gulf source stated that OPEC and Non-OPEC are not yet ready to fully lift controls and that any adjustment in oil output will be gradual, although no decision has been made yet. (Newswires)

Iran oil minister asks OPEC to support Iran in its coming struggle with the US sanctions defining them 'illegal, unilateral, extraterritorial' and demands to place the US sanctions topic on the agenda at its next meeting on June 22nd. (Newswires)
 

GEOPOLITICAL

White House Press Secretary Sanders said the US continues to prepare for the 12th June North Korea summit and that preparations have been positive so far. (Newswires)
 

US

Fed Beige Book stated the US economy expanded moderately in late April and beginning of May with few shifts in growth pattern and that manufacturing moved into 'higher gear' with more than half of Fed districts reporting a pickup in industrial activity. Furthermore, it added that employment increased at modest/moderate rate and that price and wage increases were modest. (Newswires)

US Federal Reserve and financial regulators have revealed proposals to ease the Volcker Rule which bans banks from prop trading. (Newswires)

US President Trump Lawyer Giuliani said the President is working on Q&A preparation for the Mueller investigation. (Newswires)

US GDP 2nd Estimate (Q1) 2.2% vs. Exp. 2.3% (Prev. 2.3%)
US GDP Consumer Spending Prelim (Q1) 1.0% vs. Exp. 1.2% (Prev. 1.1%)
US Wholesale Inventories Adv (Apr) 0.0% (Prev. 0.3%, Rev. 0.2%)
US Retail Inventories Advance (Apr) 0.5% (Prev. -0.1%, Rev. -0.5%)
US ADP National Employment (May) 178k vs. Exp. 190k (Prev. 204k, Rev. 163k)
 

MARKET RECAP

US Equity futures rebounded from yesterday’s sell-off, which many analysts believed to be overdone; UBS noted that S&P500 revenue exposure to Europe and Italy is only about 10% and 1% respectively, so overall the impact of the political woes in Italy to US equities is likely to be minimal. The Emini S&P 500 grinded higher overnight before being boosted at the US cash open and breaking back above the 100dma at 2712, (which was breached to the downside yesterday), and then finding resistance with the familiar 2730 level. Sector wise, energy outperformed following higher oil prices and hawkish OPEC chatter; financials also outperformed, regaining some of yesterday’s losses thanks to higher yields and a reduced US concern over Italian politics. On the negative side, utilities and technology underperformed, but still closed green. Of note for financial names, the Federal Reserve and financial regulators unveiled proposals to ease the Volcker Rule. It has tailored the strictest requirements to the top 40 most active prop trading banks, relieving the smaller banks. Banks with under USD 10bln in trading assets would see the adjustments ease hedging, market making and underwriting exemptions. The adjustments also removes the 60 day “rebuttable presumption” where it considers investments which are held for less than 60 days, are considered a prop trade, and therefore illegal. SPX 1.27% at 2724, NDX +0.72% at 6976, DJI +1.26% at 24668.

Treasuries edged lower on Wednesday as equities steadied and oil rebounded amid easing political concerns over in Europe, yet no government has been formed in Italy. Some analysts were noting that volume was elevated across the curve as attention shifted to the September contracts (June contracts expires on 20th June). Most of the action was concentrated on the front end of the curve where 2yr and 5yr yields were higher by c.1bps. Although yields were higher, modest flattening was seen across the yield curve. However, 2s30s and 5s30s narrowed by c.5bps and 2s10s and 5s10s narrowed by c.5bps. US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 20 ticks lower at 120-19+.

US MARKET WRAP 30 May 2018: Risk assets see relief rally
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • * SNAP-SHOT: Equities up, Treasuries down, DXY down, WTI up
  • * REAR-VIEW: European Politics, BoC Rate Decision, US PCE & GDP, ADP National Employment, US Advance Goods Trade Balance
  • * AHEAD: API after-market; Chinese Manufacturing PMI and Australian Capital Expenditure overnight; US Personal Consumption, Initial Jobless Claims and Canadian GDP, EZ Flash CPI, Fed's Brainard, Bostic and BoC's Leduc to speak, DoE on Thurs
  •  

*EUROPEAN POLITICS: A second attempt made to form a M5S-League government in Italy failed on Wednesday, with both parties initially uttering to be unwilling to hold talks. Later, the M5S called for euro-sceptic economist Savona to withdraw his candidacy as Economy Minister, which if he agreed, would pave way for the formation of a coalition government; 5SM leader Di Maio noted Savona should still be part of a coalition government, but not as Economy Minister, while urging that the alternative Economy Minister would try and renegotiate treaties in the EU. In response, Salvini dismissed the suggestion, saying we cannot swap ministers around. Amid to toing and froing, Italy’s President Mattarella and PM-designate Cottarelli met on Wednesday and urged not to rush the situation, and allow time to see if a government can be formed. Mattarella expressed his preference to avoid elections in summer. Salvini also appealed against a July 29th vote, though he wants elections to take place as soon as possible, adding the League will not block rapid political solutions to solve emergencies. M5S leader DI Maio said he would like to see Conte as PM or a new vote, with hopes that his party will be able to form a government alone, whilst the League’s Salvini presented Giorgetti as potential PM. Finally, ECB sources reported the ECB sees no need to intervene in the Italian crisis and suggested it does not have the tools or mandate to solve the crisis. M5S leader Di Maio already noted the ECB is reportedly buying fewer Italian bonds than before in its QE programme. Meanwhile, the latest opinion poll by Ipsos showed support for the League up by 8ppts to 25.4%, while support for 5SM was unchanged at 32.6%. Over in Spain, the Spanish opposition was seen close to securing votes necessary to remove current PM Rajoy in Friday’s confidence vote, and the PP party said to most likely see a defeat.

*BANK OF CANADA: As expected, the BOC held rates at 1.25%, though it issued a hawkish statement that raises the spectre of a rate rise in July (the probability of a July hike jumped to around 80% vs 50%). With regards to the statement itself, BOC dropped its previous reference to “cautious” policy adjustments, and higher rates will be warranted to keep inflation near target. The Bank did say it will take a gradual approach to lifting rates. Elsewhere, it repeated familiar warnings that it has made in recent month, that trade risks are weighing on business investment, while there have been stresses observed in some EM markets. “All things considered, the Bank appears to be positioning itself to raise interest rates again later this year, possibly as soon as July, but we still doubt it will follow through,” writes Capital Economics, “not with the US likely to ratchet up trade tensions by imposing steel tariffs on Canada later this week, and not with financial markets likely to remain on edge ahead of new elections in Italy”. Focus tomorrow is on BoC’s Leduc due to speak.

*US-SINO TRADE CONFLICT: China announced it will further cut import tariffs for consumer goods, namely clothing, sports apparel, shoes, washing machines, fridges, cosmetics, healthcare and food items from July 1st. China also urged state-owned companies to limit overseas investment risk, according to People's Daily, as the US prepares to announce measures in June. The WSJ reported China is reportedly seeking to line-up countries against the US. US Trade Advisor Navarro told NPR that last week's comments by US Treasury Secretary Mnuchin that the US/China trade war was over was "an unfortunate soundbite", suggesting that the US remains at (trade) war with China.

*GEOPOLITICS: White House Press Secretary Sanders says the US continues to prepare for the 12th June North Korea summit; preparations have been positive so far. US Secretary of State Pompeo told Russia Foreign Minister Lavrov that the US seeks improved ties with Russia. Elsewhere, reports citing the CIA suggest that the US intelligence community believes that North Korea has no intention of giving up its nuclear programme.

*DATA: US Q1 GDP (second estimate) moderated slightly from 2.3% to 2.2%, though the narrative seems to have changed recently as in the components, whilst inventories fell, intellectual property investment and final sales to domestic buyers rose significantly. Even though growth was revised moderately lower, it is expected to pick up in Q2, to between 3.0% and 3.5%, Capital Economics says. US Advance Goods Trade Balance fell in April to USD 68.2bln from USD 68.3bln as imports largely surpassed exports with most of the fall attributed to a USD 1.6bln drop in the industrial supplies’ deficit. Analysts at Pantheon Macroeconomics believe that imports ‘have some way to fall’ though exports also continue to underperform, weighing further on the trade balance. US ADP National Employment rose in May and came in at 178k, slightly short expectations at 190k. The softer estimate may indicate a softer payroll number for Friday’s official NFP estimate, economists said. Pantheon noted that it was unclear whether the weaker estimates were driven by lower labour demand or by insufficient supply of qualified workers. Nonetheless, given that regional reports released in May rebounded strongly, there are good reasons to believe not much has changed in the labour market and even if payrolls were to slip below 200k, the drop would be temporary, as underlying employment trend remains robust.

*FED BEIGE BOOK: The US economy expanded moderately in late April and beginning of May with few shifts in growth pattern, the latest Beige Book revealed. Manufacturing moved into 'higher gear' with more than half of Fed districts reporting a pickup in industrial activity; employment increased at modest-to-moderate rate, prices rose moderately, with the remainder reporting slight or modest increases. And wage increases were modest, with some districts expecting similar employment and wage gains in the coming months.

*EQUITIES: SPX 1.27% at 2724, NDX +0.72% at 6976, DJI +1.26% at 24668.  SECTORS: Cons Cyclicals +0.83%, Cons Non-Cyclicals: +1.38%, Energy: +3.01%, Financials: +1.82%, Health Care: +1.36%, Industrials: +1.24%, Materials: +1.15%, Telecom: +0.74%, Tech: %, Utilities: +0.69%

US Equity futures rebounded from yesterday’s sell-off, which many analysts believed to be overdone; UBS noted that S&P500 revenue exposure to Europe and Italy is only about 10% and 1% respectively, so overall the impact of the political woes in Italy to US equities is likely to be minimal. The Emini S&P 500 grinded higher overnight before being boosted at the US cash open and breaking back above the 100dma at 2712, (which was breached to the downside yesterday), and then finding resistance with the familiar 2730 level.

Sector wise, energy outperformed following higher oil prices and hawkish OPEC chatter; financials also outperformed, regaining some of yesterday’s losses thanks to higher yields and a reduced US concern over Italian politics. On the negative side, utilities and technology underperformed, but still closed green.

Of note for financial names, the Federal Reserve and financial regulators unveiled proposals to ease the Volcker Rule. It has tailored the strictest requirements to the top 40 most active prop trading banks, relieving the smaller banks. Banks with under USD 10bln in trading assets would see the adjustments ease hedging, market making and underwriting exemptions. The adjustments also removes the 60 day “rebuttable presumption” where it considers investments which are held for less than 60 days, are considered a prop trade, and therefore illegal.

Stock specific stories: Michael Kors (KORS) weighed on Wednesday following a poor earnings report, where revenue outlook was lowered due to an expected reduction in shipments following higher fuel prices, and also concerns about its Jimmy Choo business putting pressure on EPS in Q2 and Q4 of 2019. However, its EPS and revenue was relatively in line with expectations, but investors focused on the poor outlook which saw the stock fall lower than 12%. Boosting the SPX a few energy names led the index following hefty increases in oil prices, but as a result airline names underperformed on Wednesday trade.  Monster Beverages (MNST) an outperformer today following a new USD 500mln share buyback programme. Another notable story today, Dick’s Sporting Goods (DKS) had a solid earnings report beating on both the top and bottom end, along with also raising its FY18 guidance which saw the stock hit intraday highs of ~30%.

M&A news today was relatively light, however in late trade Dealreporter stated that China’s MOFCOM has halted its review of NXP semiconductors (NXPI) and Qualcomm (QCOM).

*CRUDE: WTI settles $1.48 higher at $68.21/bbl; Brent settles $2.11 higher at $77.50/bbl. Crude was on the front foot in pre-markets as safe haven demand eased slightly; additionally, reports that loadings data showed Forties supply was set to fall to an 11-month low added bullish support. The main story of the day, however, was a sources report suggesting that OPEC and Non-OPEC were not yet ready to fully lift supply curbs, and any adjustment to oil output will be gradual, according to a Gulf source; the report also added that no decision has been made yet. Elsewhere, Kazakhstan was reportedly in talks with non-OPEC allies to ease supply curbs; Indonesian oil output was reportedly running around 737k BPD (its 2018 target is 800k BPD). The Iran oil minister asked OPEC the cartel support Iran in its coming struggle with the US sanctions defining them 'illegal, unilateral, extraterritorial' and demanded to place the US sanctions topic on the agenda at its next meeting on June 22nd. The UAE minister said Iran’s request may be discussed at the June OPEC meeting.

*BRENT-WTI ARB: The widening spread between Brent and WTI prices have been driven higher by the geopolitical risk premium contained in Brent (NOTE: the July contract expires on Thursday), and was around $9 on Wednesday. The widening spread is said to be beneficial for US crude exporters, given the competitive price edge. However, WTI prices are being constrained by supply bottlenecks, as well as an aging infrastructure. PVM points out that there is only one oil terminal in the US that can handle supertankers, while a lack of pipeline capacity in the Permian basin is preventing crude from flowing to the Gulf Coast export hub. Citi's analysts suggest that the lack of pipeline capacity is causing some oversupply in some producing regions, adding negative drivers to WTI prices, but the Bank doubts that there is truth to reports that Texas pipelines are at or close to their limit. In fact, other reports have suggested that US export capacity is currently around 3.5mln BPD, around 1mln bbls above the current levels of exports, suggesting that there remains room for US exporters to meet additional demand int he short-term, as a result of favourable arbitrage economics.

*ENERGY INVENTORIES: After the bell, the API will report energy inventories for the week; the Street looks for crude stocks to draw by 0.5mln bbls, distillates to draw by 1.3mln, and gasoline to draw by 1.4mln.

*FIXED INCOME: US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 20 ticks lower at 120-19+. Treasuries edged lower on Wednesday as equities steadied and oil rebounded amid easing political concerns over in Europe, yet no government has been formed in Italy. Some analysts were noting that volume was elevated across the curve as attention shifted to the September contracts (June contracts expires on 20th June). Most of the action was concentrated on the front end of the curve where 2yr and 5yr yields were higher by c.1bps. Although yields were higher, modest flattening was seen across the yield curve. However, 2s30s and 5s30s narrowed by c.5bps and 2s10s and 5s10s narrowed by c.5bps.

*FOREX: EUR: The single-currency bounced-back on Wednesday, rising by around 1% against the USD, consolidating around 1.1650 in afternoon trade. There hasn't been any marked shift in the narrative, and some were suggesting that the heavy buying at the European open was simply a short-squeeze. (With regards to Italian BTPs, some desks were talking about profit-taking on shorts, given that we have dropped so quickly). In fact, one desk noted that given Bund/BTP spreads, the 'fair value' of EURUSD is around 1.10. There was attention on a Goldman Sachs note, where the bank said it sees EURUSD around 1.15 over the next three-months, and cut it's 12-month forecast to 1.25 from 1.30.

JPY, CHF, XAU: Rising rates and a more constructive risk tone helped the USD to advance against haven FX, with USDJPY consolidating just beneath the 109 figure. The Swissy, however, remained bid against the USD though was down against the EUR, while gold managed to keep its head above $1300. Some desks prefer fading EURCHF rallies around 1.1530 given the lingering political risks in the Eurozone. But with that said, traders are wary of the risks of going long Swiss given the SNB's history of intervention in FX.

CAD: A double-whammy of bullish pressures helped CAD outperform. USDCAD was straddling 1.30 ahead of the BOC meeting, and following a hawkish hold, USDCAD dropped to successfully test the 1.29 handle, and consolidated beneath the figure until an OPEC sources report lifted crude, buoying CAD further.

AUD, NZD: The Kiwi has flown to the top of the G10 pile and stretched its lead over the AUD in the process as the cross hovers just above 1.0800. A broad upturn in risk appetite and sentiment after the extreme aversion prompted by latest Italian political developments has helped the NZD to rebound over 0.6950 vs the USD and retest offers/resistance ahead of 0.7000, while AUDUSD has struggled to clear 0.7550 convincingly amidst more US-China trade barbs and bartering.

EMFX: The softer dollar and more constructive risk tone helped the complex bounce. MXN's gains were more muted however, amid continuing uncertainty around NAFTA as well as the upcoming Mexican elections on 1 July; higher US rates were also cited as holding back the peso's gains. Elsewhere, the Banxico’s inflation report kept growth forecasts unchanged, adding that it saw inflation falling in 2018 to close to 3%, while also talking about the familiar risks faced by the Mexican economy. Despite a wider budget deficit, the ZAR gained over 1% vs the USD, with greenback weakness being cited, as well as higher commodity prices – RUB also gained on commodity prices. TRY's ascendancy continues, and there was further upside against the dollar on Wednesday after the Turkish central bank said it will continue the use of all available instruments to achieve price stability, and added that a tight stance in monetary policy will be maintained and if needed further tightening will be delivered. The BRL was weaker against the USD, however, after Q1 GDP data only grew modestly and below consensus expectations; analysts warn of a cloudy outlook ahead. Additionally, news that Brazil's Petrobras will raise gasoline prices weighed.

Daily FX Wrap: some respite after Roman risk rout, Loonie leaps on hawkish BoC guidance
content:
NZD/AUD

The Kiwi has flown to the top of the G10 pile and stretched its lead over the Aud in the process as the cross hovers just above 1.0800. A broad upturn in risk appetite and sentiment after the extreme aversion prompted by latest Italian political developments has helped the Nzd to rebound over 0.6950 vs the Usd and retest offers/resistance ahead of 0.7000, while Aud/Usd has struggled to clear 0.7550 convincingly amidst more US-China trade barbs and bartering.

CAD

Firmer for the most part and gathering strength temporarily post-Canadian data that was arguably better or not as bad as US releases at the same time, but the Loonie really took off and traded through 1.2900 vs its US counterpart on the back of a hawkish hold from the BoC. In short, the cautious caveat on monetary policy was removed from the accompanying statement and the economic outlook upgraded to warrant tightening in order that inflation remains close to target. Note, option break-evens on the event indicated a 90 pip move, and this was surpassed on balance as Usd/Cad was nearer 1.3000 pre-BoC.  

EUR  

Off best levels, but holding the bulk of its recovery gains vs the Greenback around 1.1610 on less angst regarding the situation in Rome and after contrasting Eurozone vs US data (former mostly stronger than expected and latter vice-versa). However, the heat now turns up on Spain’s PM Rajoy who appears resigned to losing a vote of no confidence in Madrid and this could spark a fresh bout of market mayhem.

GBP/CHF

Both holding gains vs the Dollar after some volatile price action and little fresh in terms of UK or Swiss specific drivers – Cable approaching 1.3300 and briefly above the big figure, Usd/Chf easing below 0.9900 and Eur/Chf sub-1.1500.

JPY  

Rangebound vs the Usd between 108.35-109.00, and mainly towards the upper end after climbing from overnight lows alongside a broad shift in tone from risk-off to back on again, albeit partially/selectively.

EM

Decent recovery gains across the board, as the DXY eased back further from Tuesday’s 95.030 ytd peaks and hawkish CBRT minutes gave the TRY more momentum.

subject: RANsquawk Daily US Opening News - 30th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Italian politics still dominate European markets as political turmoil continues
  • EUR/USD back above 1.16 after upticks in regional German CPIs
  • Looking ahead, highlights include, US ADP, GDP, Advance Good Trade Balance, BoC Rate Decision, APIs

 

ASIA-PAC

Asian stocks traded lower across the board on spill-over selling from Wall St, with global market sentiment daunted by political uncertainty in Europe and trade concerns after reports the US plans to proceed with tech tariffs and investment restrictions on China. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) were both negative with declines led by financials following hefty losses in the sector stateside which dropped over 3% amid a slump in yields, although losses in Australia were stemmed by gains in defensive stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) underperformed on prospects of trade tariffs which outweighed another consecutive firm liquidity effort by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded higher and above the 151.00 level as yields tracked the downside in their US and most European counterparts, aside from Italian government bonds which tumbled on the political disarray and dampened rate hike probabilities for both the ECB and Fed.

China stated the US announcement of plans to proceed with tariffs is contrary to previous consensus and stated it is capable of protecting its own interests no matter what the US does. In related news, there were also reports that the US is said to plan imposing restrictions on some China visas. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 110bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 60bln in 14-day reverse repos and CNY 100bln via 28-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 70bln. (Newswires)

PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4207 (Prev. 6.4021)

EU/UK/US                     

Italy PM designate Cottarelli met again with Mattarella at the Qurinale today, with no press release post the meeting. This is after ANSA reported that Cottarelli was considering giving up the mandate, allowing for a possible election on July 29th, but a source close to Mattarella later stated there was no mention of this and that he asked for more time to name a cabinet. Comments from the populists also transpired, with calls for early elections and the backing of Giorgetti for PM by the League and Conte by 5SM. Both parties also reiterated the intention to form a government but have emphasized the likelihood of a snap election. (Newswires)

Spain's Ciudadanos proposed to the Spanish social-democratic party that Redondo, Jauregui or Solana lead the motion of no confidence instead of Sanchez (Newswires)

EU Consumer Confidence Final (May) 0.2 vs. Exp. 0.2 (Prev. 0.3)

German Saxony State CPI MM (May) 0.5% (Prev. 0.0%)

German Saxony State CPI YY (May) 2.2% (Prev. 1.6%)

German Unemployment Rate SA (May) 5.2% vs. Exp. 5.3% (Prev. 5.3%)

Swedish GDP YY (Q1) 3.3% vs. Exp. 3.4% (Prev. 3.3%, Rev. 2.9%)

Swedish GDP QQ (Q1) 0.7% vs. Exp. 0.5% (Prev. 0.9%, Rev. 0.7%)

GEOPOLITICS

White House Press Secretary Sanders said US President Trump thinks discussions with North Korea are proceeding well and added the White House prepared for summit to take place June 12th. (Newswires)

North Korea renewed its demand for US and South Korea to cancel military exercises in August, while there were also unconfirmed reports that North Korea was said to have conducted a torpedo test during talks with South Korea and US, although timing is uncertain. Furthermore, Axios noted a CIA assessment report which stated that North Korea will not denuclearize. (Newswires/Twitter/Axios)

Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov will visit North Korea tomorrow. (Newswires)

EQUITIES

European equities have traded in a particularly choppy fashion with the FTSE MIB fluctuating between gains and losses (+1.0%) as markets remain sensitive to the latest developments in Italian politics. Broadly, investors are reassessing the likelihood of an Italian departure from the EUR after yesterday’s market frenzy, but the outcome of negotiations remains far from clear. Some Italian bank stocks continues to suffer with Bper Banca (-0.7%). Elsewhere, Vivendi (-4%) shares are lower on the loss of broadcasting rights for the French football league, while Bayer (+3.8%) received US approval for the Monsanto takeover, lending support to their shares.

FX

A marked change in fortunes for the EUR on a combination of firmer than expected macro releases (German retail sales, state CPIs, jobs and Spanish inflation) and further respite in Italian markets, with the single currency eclipsing Tuesday’s recovery high vs the USD and reclaiming the 1.1600 handle at one stage. However, Italy’s political situation remains up in the air after no progress on an interim Government and heightened prospects of another election within the next few months.

Hence, safe-havens like the JPY and CHF retain a firm underlying bid (circa 0.9900 and sub-109.00 vs the Greenback and sub-1.1500/126.00 vs the Eur respectively) despite more verbal intervention from the SNB (Jordan reiterating the need for NIRP and direct intervention given fragile currency markets).

NZD/AUD the next best G10 performers, or rebounders from recent lows to be more precise, as the antipodeans revisit 0.6950 and 0.7500+ levels vs the Usd respectively amidst a general improvement in risk sentiment, which has offset data misses overnight (in the form of NZ and Aussie building permits).

GBP/CAD both largely side-lined, but also unwinding some losses with Cable back over 1.3250 and the Loonie firming through 1.3000 ahead of the BoC policy meeting and a raft of Canadian data in the run up. Note, options indicate another rhefty break-even on the central bank event of 90 pips.

SEK

Solid Swedish GDP data has underpinned the Krona and nudged Eur/Sek down through 10.3000.

FIXED INCOME

The broad recovery in Italian BTPs remains intact as the 10 year bond holds at the upper end of a 122.74-125.18 range (and vs Tuesday’s deep 120.10 fire-sale low), while Bunds have slipped to a fresh Eurex base at 161.65 (-115 ticks) in wake of more above forecast German state inflation data that underscores an upside skew for the pan release. Conversely, Gilts are back on an even keel and recently retested Liffe peaks and the Short Sterling strip has flipped to mildly positive territory on little obvious in the way of UK or independent impetus, but Brexit uncertainty still a factor. Back to Italy, and the looming month end issuance is an obvious near term supply driver, but aside from the clear concession (notwithstanding the retreat in yields), index and redemption dynamics could entice investors and offset some of the ongoing political rationale that may put off buyers. In the event, auction results were relatively solid, albeit with yields significantly higher and BTP futures are retreating after some initial choppy price action.

COMMODITIES

Commodities are steady during early European trade with WTI crude futures marginally higher after somewhat choppy Asia trade and with resistance at the USD 67/bbl level, while focus for oil now shifts to the API inventory report after-market in US which was delayed due to the extended weekend.

Gold is trading flat, now back below the 1300 level as the risk premium starts to unwind following yesterday’s safe-haven bid. Meanwhile, London copper (-0.8%) flirts around three-week lows on the broad-risk averse tone seen during Asia-Pac trade amid underperformance in its largest consumer China.

content: Extremely choppy trade at the start of Wednesday’s session, with the 10 year German benchmark opening 24 ticks higher at 163.04 and inching up another 2 ticks from yesterday’s 162.80 close before hitting offers and reversing all the way down to 162.21 before finding some underlying bids. The initial mark-up defied bearish leads from US Treasuries and less stress in Italian bonds after Tuesday’s meltdown even though the political scene is arguably less clear following no agreement on an interim Government between the President and proposed caretaker PM. Bunds may have paid some heed to much stronger than forecast German retail sales, but upcoming state and national CPI data is likely to impact much more if outside consensus. Also ahead, the latest unemployment report and pan Eurozone sentiment indices before the focus switches back to Italy for end of month BTP issuance.

content:
**EUROPEAN EQUITY COVERAGE WILL ONLY COVER COMPANIES IN THE STOXX 600 OR COMPANIES OF SYSTEMIC IMPORTANCE TO PARTICULAR SECTORS**

30th May 2018

The Daily European Equity Opening News is uploaded at 0700BST/0100CDT recapping all of the overnight equity news

From 0700BST/0100CDT all equity news will be covered in real time over the audio and headline feed and the full audio rundown will be at 0715BST/0115CDT.

There will be an additional audio rundown at 0750BST/0150CDT recapping any company news which has hit the wires since 0715BST/0115CDT ahead of the European equity open

ASIA

Asian stocks traded lower across the board on spill-over selling from Wall St, with global market sentiment daunted by political uncertainty in Europe and trade concerns after reports the US plans to proceed with tech tariffs and investment restrictions on China. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) were both negative with declines led by financials following hefty losses in the sector stateside which dropped over 3% amid a slump in yields, although losses in Australia were stemmed by gains in defensive stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) underperformed on prospects of trade tariffs which outweighed another consecutive firm liquidity effort by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded higher and above the 151.00 level as yields tracked the downside in their US and most European counterparts, aside from Italian government bonds which tumbled on the political disarray and dampened rate hike probabilities for both the ECB and Fed.

FTSE

FTSE 100 RESHUFFLE – Ocado (OCDO LN) and GVC (GVC LN) replacing G4S (GFS LN) and Mediclinic (MDC LN)

Shire (SHP LN) – Co.’s takeover by Takeda Pharmaceutical is coming under pressure from Takeda shareholders with twelve investors now having raised concerns that the deal “carries overly high risks” and that “there is a danger of causing a great disadvantage to existing shareholders”. (Times)

RBS (RBS LN) – The shadow chancellor has called for the government to use its stake in the co. to stop planned branch closures. (Guardian)

Rolls Royce (RR/ LN) – The co. has tripled the capacity available in order to fix problems with the Trent 1000 engine. The engine that powers Boeings 787 Dreamliner has both compressor blade and turbine blade problems, and has led to the grounding of various flights up until the problems can be fixed. (FT)

Glencore (GLEN LN) – Co.’s Rolleston mine is said to be subject to various PE interest. (Newswires)

OTHER UK COMPANIES

Derriston Capital (DERR LN) – Sir Martin Sorrell is set to make a comeback at Derriston as the co.’s Chairman. (Sky News)

Vedanta (VED LN) – The co. is planning litigation over the closure of their Indian copper smelter. (Newswires)

RyanAir (RYA LN) – Management of the Co. is set to meeting with pilot unions amid threats of strike action, according to reports. (Newswires)

DAX

Bayer (BAYN GY) / BASF (BAS GY) – Bayer has agreed to sell agricultural businesses and assets worth USD 9bln to BASF as part of the agreement with US DoJ. (Newswires) 

Daimler (DAI GY) – The co. have taken a stake in the Estonian start-up Taxify, a ride on demand app. This investment values the start up at around USD 1bln. (FT)

BROKER MOVES

LINDE (LIN GY) UPGRADED TO OVERWEIGHT FROM NEUTRAL AT JP MORGAN CHASE

CAC

Peugeot (UG FP) – Opel agree job guarantees for workers in German regions until summer 2023. (Newswires)

Vivendi (VIV FP) – The co.’s branch Canal+ has not won the rights to post-2020 French football league broadcasting rights. (Newswires)

Carrefour (CA FP) – Co. are looking at moving some of their hypermarket space for other uses, according to reports. (Newswires)

Total (FP FP) – The Brazilian environmental agency rejected the co.’s application for a licence to drill in the Foz do Amazonas basin. (Newswires)

BROKER MOVES

PAN EUROPE

subject: RANsquawk Daily European Opening News - 30th May 2018
content:
To download the report, please click here
If you would like to subscribe to receive the research sheets directly in your inbox, you can no do so under the Research Suite section of the portal.
To subscribe simply check the box next to "Email these reports" under the desired category.

  • Asian equities trade lower across the board as Italian political woes and trade concerns grip sentiment overnight
  • Cottarelli and Mattarella failed to reach an agreement on forming a government but will continue talks. ANSA report that failure to reach a deal could see elections on July 29th
  • Looking ahead, highlights include regional and national German CPIs, US ADP, GDP, Advance Good Trade Balance, BoC Rate Decision, APIs

 

ASIA

Asian stocks traded lower across the board on spill-over selling from Wall St, with global market sentiment daunted by political uncertainty in Europe and trade concerns after reports the US plans to proceed with tech tariffs and investment restrictions on China. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) were both negative with declines led by financials following hefty losses in the sector stateside which dropped over 3% amid a slump in yields, although losses in Australia were stemmed by gains in defensive stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) underperformed on prospects of trade tariffs which outweighed another consecutive firm liquidity effort by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded higher and above the 151.00 level as yields tracked the downside in their US and most European counterparts, aside from Italian government bonds which tumbled on the political disarray and dampened rate hike probabilities for both the ECB and Fed.

China stated the US announcement of plans to proceed with tariffs is contrary to previous consensus and stated it is capable of protecting its own interests no matter what the US does. In related news, there were also reports that the US is said to plan imposing restrictions on some China visas. (Newswires)

PBoC injected CNY 110bln via 7-day reverse repos, CNY 60bln in 14-day reverse repos and CNY 100bln via 28-day reverse repos for a net daily injection of CNY 70bln. (Newswires)
PBoC set CNY mid-point at 6.4207 (Prev. 6.4021)
 

UK/EU

Italy PM designate Cottarelli left the meeting with Italian’s President Mattarella, where no outcome was reached on forming a government, but reports suggested he will try again today. ANSA then reported Cottarelli was considering giving up the mandate, allowing for a possible election on July 29th, but a source close to Mattarella later stated there was no mention of this and that he asked for more time to name a cabinet. Separately, a spokeswoman to EU’s Juncker said Juncker is convinced that “Italy’s fate does not lie in the hands of the financial markets”. (Newswires)


Italy’s Five Star leader Di Maio said the hypothesis of impeachment is no longer on the table and that he is ready to work with Italy’s President Mattarella, while Italy's Democratic Party called for immediate dissolution of Parliament and snap election according to a lawmaker. (ANSA/Newswires)

ECB’s Lautenschlaeger (Hawk) said a first hike around middle of 2019 is not entirely out of the ballpark and thinks June may be the month to decide a gradual QE exit. (Newswires)  

UK BRC Shop Price Index (May) Y/Y -1.1% (Prev. -1.0%). (Newswires)


FX

JPY held on to most its recent the gains amid the widespread risk averse tone with USD/JPY and JPY-crosses within ongoing downward channels which began last week, while the USD also remained firm on safe-haven bids and with EUR/USD stuck around 10-month lows near the 1.1500 level due to the ongoing European political uncertainty. Furthermore, the PBoC continued to weaken the fix and EM currencies extended on losses with PHP the notable underperformer as it neared a 12-year low against the greenback. Antipodeans also languished with AUD/USD below 0.7500 while NZD/USD struggled to reclaim the 0.6900 handle for most the session following disappointing Building Approvals data.

SNB’s Chairman Jordan said monetary policy of negative interest rates and FX intervention takes into account market fragility, while he also added that developments in recent days show the situation of the currency market does remain fragile. (Newswires)

Australian Building Approvals (Apr) M/M -5.0% vs. Exp. -3.0% (Prev. 2.6%, Rev. 3.5%). (Newswires)
Australian Building Approvals (Apr) Y/Y 1.9% vs. Exp. 4.1% (Prev. 14.5%, Rev. 15.6%)
New Zealand Building Permits (Apr) -3.7% (Prev. 14.7%, Rev. 13.0%)


COMMODITIES

Commodities were subdued during Asia hours with WTI crude futures flat after somewhat choppy trade and with resistance at the USD 67/bbl level, while focus for oil now shifts to the API inventory report after-market in US which is delayed due to the extended weekend. Gold also traded flat with safe-haven bids nullified by an unwavering greenback, while copper languished near this week’s lows on the broad-risk averse tone and underperformance in its largest consumer China.

CME raised Nymex crude oil maintenance margins to USD 2550 per contract from USD 2450 per contract for July. (Newswires)

Ecuador’s Oil Minister stated that OPEC should maintain output cuts at the June meeting, while he added that the latest price fall is a blip and suggests oil prices are not likely to vary strongly. (Newswires)

US could spare EN+ from sanctions if Deripaska reduces stake in the group. (Twitter)


GEOPOLITICS

White House Press Secretary Sanders said US President Trump thinks discussions with North Korea are proceeding well and added the White House prepared for summit to take place June 12th. (Newswires)

North Korea renewed its demand for US and South Korea to cancel military exercises in August, while there were also unconfirmed reports that North Korea was said to have conducted a torpedo test during talks with South Korea and US, although timing is uncertain. Furthermore, Axios noted a CIA assessment report which stated that North Korea will not denuclearize. (Newswires/Twitter/Axios)

North Korean Vice Chairman Kim Yong Chol is to meet with US Secretary of State Pompeo later this week. (Newswires)

Russian Foreign Minister Lavrov will visit North Korea soon, according to North Korean state media. (KCNA)


US

Treasury yields fell on political concerns in Italy/Spain, sending yields on 10-year Tsys back to 2.80%, and the long-end back beneath 3.00%. The 2s10s spread flattened to narrows last seen in 2007, while 2s5s fell 3bps; that said, there was some widening observed in 5s30s which, at settlement, was around 5bps wider. Given the political concerns in Europe, there was much focus on ECB rate pricing, and unsurprisingly, the buying of the curve pushed implied probabilities of rate hikes further out, with the first rate hike not fully priced until the latter part of next year. There was a similar reaction in Fed pricing, with the odds of a rate hike easing to around 75% (from around 97% at the beginning of May). US 10yr T-Notes futures settled 44 ticks higher at 121-07+.

ASIA-PAC MARKET WRAP: Asia stocks sold off following Wall St. slump due to EU political uncertainty and tariff threat
content: Asia stocks traded lower across the board on spill-over selling from Wall St, with global market sentiment daunted by political uncertainty in Europe and on trade concerns after reports the US plans to proceed with tech tariffs and investment restrictions on China. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.6%) were both negative with declines led by financials following hefty losses in the sector stateside which dropped over 3% amid a slump in yields, although losses in Australia were stemmed by gains in defensive stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-1.8%) and Hang Seng (-1.5%) underperformed on prospects of trade tariffs which outweighed another consecutive firm liquidity effort by the PBoC. Finally, 10yr JGBs traded higher and above the 151.00 level as yields tracked the downside in their US and most European counterparts, aside from Italian government bonds which tumbled on the political disarray and dampened rate hike probabilities for both the ECB and Fed.

ASIA-PAC MID-SESSION UPDATE: Asia stocks sold off following Wall St. slump on EU political uncertainty and tariff threat
content:
Asia stocks trade lower across the board on spill-over selling from Wall St, with global market sentiment daunted by political uncertainty in Europe and on trade concerns after reports the US plans to proceed with tech tariffs and investment restrictions on China. ASX 200 (-0.6%) and Nikkei 225 (-1.8%) are both negative with declines led by financials following hefty losses in the sector stateside which dropped over 3% amid a slump in yields, although losses in Australia have been stemmed by gains in defensive stocks. Elsewhere, Shanghai Comp. (-2.1%) and Hang Seng (-1.7%) are also similarly pressured on prospects of trade tariffs which outweighed another consecutive firm liquidity effort by the PBoC.

In FX markets, JPY holds on to the gains amid the widespread risk averse tone with USD/JPY and JPY-crosses within ongoing downward channels which began last week, while the USD also remains firm on safe-haven bids and with EUR/USD stuck around 10-month lows near the 1.1500 level amid the ongoing European political uncertainty. Furthermore, the PBoC continued to weaken the fix and EM currencies extended on losses with PHP notably underperforming as it nears a 12-year low against the greenback. Antipodeans also languish with AUD/USD below 0.7500 and NZD/USD struggling to gain a footing on the 0.6900 handle following disappointing Building Approvals data.

Finally, 10yr JGBs trade higher and above 151.00 as yields track the downside in their US counterparts triggered by political disarray, which dampened rate hike probabilities for both the ECB and Fed.
